posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
In pyfrc 2025.1.0 I’ve added a new ‘isolated’ mode for running the robot tests. Instead of trying to reset the python process and wpilib before each test, each individual test is ran in a new python process. I hope that this will eliminate a variety of issues that teams have run into when running the robot tests.

There are two ways to enable this in your robot tests. You can run your tests via robotpy test --isolated , or (preferred) you can add the following to pyproject.toml :

Please try this out and let me know how it goes. I expect to make this the only available test mode next year, assuming no major issues are discovered.

link_counts.title: Fatal Python error: Segmentation fault when using Register Telemetry in Phoenix 6 Swerve Drive API

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Currently dealing with out of disk space on a RIO1 while trying to deploy with pip.

I suspect the problem is us, using a RIO1

But as soon as that is clear, this is on our list of things to try.

Appreciate it!!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: Hm, you shouldn’t really be running out of space unless you’re doing something like logging data to the rio’s flash… or maybe the deploy program is copying a virtualenv into the rio?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Nah, this is during the pip installs before the program is copied over, and I already deleted the old user program from the py folder manually.

What I haven’t triaged is where the disk space is actually getting used … And if there’s just some massive file.

This post flagged as “off topic”

posts.name: Nathan Beasley
posts.cooked: Thanks for that update virtuald. We are making a push to integrate UT into our curriculum this year and I was able to remove my robot class singleton hack I had been using to work around it. So far this is working great.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
Nice!

Unfortunately, for the same reason I forgot about my xdist PR, we’re not running into a situation where vendor deps are tripping us up in simulation, so I’m not a good test candidate.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: @Justin_Buist my intent is to make it the default next year, so I’d like it to get as much testing as possible, so I’d love it if your team enabled it by default to see if any issues pop up.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
Gotcha. We upgraded our toolchain the other day and I had dropped in the pyproject.toml mod to make it run in isolated  mode. It caught a failure after not too long and reverted back for the day.

I’ll see if I can track down a repeatable example for you.

posts.name: Justin Buist
posts.cooked:
Here we go! Our current code is doing the failure thing in isolated mode. Error message doesn’t really clue me in to what’s happening.

Wth this code tests fail in --isolated mode but pass under the old me…

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
Ah yes, you copied 4774’s repo. The problem is the get_alliance_stations function in the fuzz tests returns a random alliance… and when we launch the new process, it’s random again. There’s probably a clever way to detect and fix it, but this is really niche so it’s probably not worth spending the time to figure out how to handle it in pyfrc.

Here’s an awful workaround:

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
por fin

image 1132×268 11.1 KB

image 1132×268 11.1 KB

image 1132×268 11.1 KB

Fixes our issues, and we were able to remove our destroyAllSingletonInstances() hack

Overall the test runs slower (the first 8 technically don’t need HAL isolation). But I like slow working tests over borked and fast.

Appreciate the hard work and ingenuity yet again!

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
In theory we could run the tests in parallel like pytest-xdist does, which could speed things up. We should also be able to detect when the robot fixture isn’t being used and not isolate those tests.

Isolated mode: only isolate tests that use the robot fixture · Issue #240 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

Isolated mode: run tests in parallel · Issue #241 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

link_counts.title: Isolated mode: run tests in parallel · Issue #241 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub
Isolated mode: only isolate tests that use the robot fixture · Issue #240 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
virtuald:

Isolated mode: run tests in parallel · Issue 241 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

Possibly!

There’s a chance you get some cross-talk on things that open ports on localhost - photonvision’s ntp-at-home, NT, our team’s insane love for web dashboards at home…

But still all a net improvement.

posts.name: Etienne Beaulac
posts.cooked: My team uses custom fixtures which are imported in a conftest.py file located at the root of our repo. It always worked great with robotpy testing, but in isolated mode, it looks like our file “overwrites” robotpy’s fixtures (i.e. the fixture robot cannot be found). When I remove the conftest.py file, I am able to run a few tests that do no require our own fixtures.
